image.altText: Michele Bullock fronting a Senate estimates hearing

items.synopsis: Michele Bullock will become the first woman to lead the Reserve Bank of Australia, replacing incumbent Philip Lowe following months of speculation about the governor's future.

title.children: Michele Bullock becomes first woman to serve as RBA governor, replacing Philip Lowe

image.altText: A middle-aged man in a dark suit holds a press conference in front of a lectern. Aboriginal and Australian flags are behind him.

items.synopsis: The pesticides authority CEO and board chair resign, after a review triggered by allegations one of the agency's workers urinated on his colleagues.

title.children: Following claims a public servant urinated on colleagues, pesticides authority CEO and board chair resign

image.altText: Australian Foreign Minister Penny Wong speaks during meeting.

items.synopsis: The Australian foreign minister says China needs to continue to free up trade for Australian products if Anthony Albanese is to visit there later this year.

title.children: Penny Wong in frank talks with China over trade and human rights at ASEAN summit

image.altText: Peter Dutton rubs his eye.

items.synopsis: The Federal by-election for the seat of Fadden could deliver a blow or a boost for Peter Dutton next week, writes Michelle Grattan.

title.children: A huge hurdle is coming for Dutton — but a bigger challenge is right behind

image.altText: A metalic Toyota symbol on a White Toyota Hi-Lux with the defective DPF.

items.synopsis: Toyota has announced a technological breakthrough in batteries, but questions have been raised over the company's dubious EV track record.

title.children: Why some EV drivers are sceptical of Toyota's battery breakthrough

image.altText: A Caucasian woman with brown hair, wearing glasses and a blazer.

items.synopsis: Incoming RBA governor Michele Bullock says she is aware of the "challenging" task she faces trying to tame inflation, after being appointed to succeed Philip Lowe. Follow live.

title.children: Incoming RBA boss says she is coming into role at 'challenging time' for economy

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Michele Bullock has spent much of her career at the central bank, but after a review of the RBA called for major change, was the internal promotion the right call for the next governor? After a brief appearance here on the blog, my colleague Michael Janda spoke to three experts to find out what they make of the decision, and what it could mean for the future of the RBA and the economy. You can read their thoughts below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Is Michele Bullock the right choice as RBA governor? Experts are divided

featuredLink.title: Is Michele Bullock the right choice as RBA governor? The experts are divided

children.content: Michele Bullock has spent much of her career at the central bank, but after a review of the RBA called for major change, was the internal promotion the right call for the next governor?
After a brief appearance here on the blog, my colleague
spoke to three experts to find out what they make of the decision, and what it could mean for the future of the RBA and the economy.
You can read their thoughts below:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Shadow Treasurer Angus Taylor has welcomed Ms Bullock's appointment, describing her as a "highly capable" economist who will lead the bank through the current economic climate. "Michele Bullock is a highly capable economist, with qualifications from the London School of Economics and University of New England, who has served the Reserve Bank with distinction for 38 years," he said in a statement. "With inflation at its highest level in three decades, it is essential Australians can have confidence in this crucial economic institution and that we continue to have a credible and capable Reserve Bank. "Families are feeling the impacts of higher prices and rising interest rates every day. Along with strong economic management, a strong Reserve Bank is essential to addressing the inflation that is driving higher prices." Mr Taylor has also paid tribute to Philip Lowe, thanking him for his years of service. "[Mr] Lowe has been an independent, distinguished, and dedicated governor who has helped to steer Australia through some of our biggest economic challenges," he said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Coalition welcomes appointment of 'highly capable' governor

children.content: Shadow Treasurer Angus Taylor has welcomed Ms Bullock's appointment, describing her as a "highly capable" economist who will lead the bank through the current economic climate.

"Michele Bullock is a highly capable economist, with qualifications from the London School of Economics and University of New England, who has served the Reserve Bank with distinction for 38 years," he said in a statement.

"With inflation at its highest level in three decades, it is essential Australians can have confidence in this crucial economic institution and that we continue to have a credible and capable Reserve Bank.

"Families are feeling the impacts of higher prices and rising interest rates every day. Along with strong economic management, a strong Reserve Bank is essential to addressing the inflation that is driving higher prices."
Mr Taylor has also paid tribute to Philip Lowe, thanking him for his years of service.
"[Mr] Lowe has been an independent, distinguished, and dedicated governor who has helped to steer Australia through some of our biggest economic challenges," he said.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The secretary for the Australian Council of Trade Unions, Sally McManus, has welcomed the federal government's decision not to re-appoint Philip Lowe as the Reserve Bank governor. She says while Mr Lowe has served the country well, it provides an opportunity for a fresh look at how the central bank goes about its business. "There's been clearly mistakes made over the last couple of years and we're hoping that the new governor does take a new approach especially in the areas of wages and understanding how wages work as well as unemployment," she says.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Unions welcome fresh appointment of new RBA governor

children.content: The secretary for the Australian Council of Trade Unions, Sally McManus, has welcomed the federal government's decision not to re-appoint Philip Lowe as the Reserve Bank governor.
She says while Mr Lowe has served the country well, it provides an opportunity for a fresh look at how the central bank goes about its business.

"There's been clearly mistakes made over the last couple of years and we're hoping that the new governor does take a new approach especially in the areas of wages and understanding how wages work as well as unemployment," she says.
